text: in Mount Lebanon 200,000 people perished
during World War one not from armed
conflict but starvation and disease you
used to see people in the dead on the
streets in the road with bloated
stomachs
Lebanon as we know it today didn't exist
before the end of the First World War
back then it was just Mount Lebanon a
mountainous semi-autonomous area under
the world's greatest Islamic power the
Ottoman Empire in 1914 the Ottoman
Empire covered 1.3 million square
kilometers of land by lying themselves
with Germany the Ottomans hoped to
expand their empire even further this
alliance proved to be devastating for
the people of Mount Lebanon
before the war the economy was largely
driven by the production of silk Fermata
was one of the largest silk reeling
factories in this room mostly women
worked the silk fibers from sunrise to
sunset the silk pie produced here were
shipped all the way to Europe mainly to
France
but in 1915 international trade routes
were cut off as the Allies imposed sea
blockades silk production plummeted
incomes dried up hunger spread across
the mountains soldiers not civilians
were the priority all resources were
confiscated for the ottoman war effort
families became desperate in my research
as I come across some terrible stories
of that period one of them is the story
of a father who came to see a priest he
wanted to confess that he ate his own
children because of starvation many
similar cases of cannibalism are seen in
the memoirs of justice
fate was to deal one more extraordinary
blow to Mount Lebanon the worst locust
attack in a generation in the Latisse
overhang at 10:00 in the morning the
locusts flew and covered the Sun and
when the swarms descended upon the
fields they stripped them of everything
really amid all the misery there were
still some who could help
several soup kitchens opened to feed
hungry mouths
Miriam Curtis was a teacher from the
village of brahmana in 1916 she and a
team of helpers began cooking for women
and children
what Miriam started here at home went on
to feed at least 1500 people from Ramana
and the neighboring villages every day
it was a joint effort by the women and
the villages to come out here and you
know do the cooking and whatever it took
to to prepare the food also people used
to come with their pots and pans usually
women to get some food for the children
there's a very pathetic sight to see and
this is what she remembers the famine of
Mount Lebanon has largely been forgotten
by the wider world but here it is still
remembered as a period of immense
suffering and loss
